This is not legal advice. For guidance tailored to your jurisdiction and situation, consult a qualified attorney.

When weighing whether to press charges against a disadvantaged thief, you might:

• Assess harm and intent: What was stolen, how much loss occurred, and was the act premeditated or born of desperation?  
• Consider personal circumstances: Does the defendant face poverty, addiction, mental‐health challenges or other hardships that drove the offense?  
• Evaluate proportionality: Would criminal prosecution be unduly harsh given the value of what was taken and the offender’s background?  
• Explore alternatives: Could diversion programs, community service, restitution agreements or restorative-justice circles better serve the interests of victims, offenders and the community?  
• Weigh public-interest factors: Would pressing charges deter future crime or simply burden the courts and perpetuate inequality?  
• Seek balanced outcomes: Aim to hold the offender accountable while addressing root causes and minimizing collateral harm.

• 1. Ensure safety  
  – Secure the environment (remove weapons, alert security/support staff)  
  – Position yourself with clear exits and within view of colleagues  

• 2. Conduct rapid assessment  
  – Evaluate patient’s mental status, risk of harm to self/others, vital signs  
  – Determine capacity to consent to treatment  

• 3. De-escalate verbally  
  – Speak calmly, use simple language, offer choices  
  – Validate fears while maintaining firm boundaries  

• 4. Follow clinical guidelines  
  – Choose medication per protocol (e.g., rapid-acting antipsychotics or benzodiazepines)  
  – Use the lowest effective dose; avoid excessive sedation  

• 5. Obtain consent or apply legal safeguards  
  – If capacitated, explain risks/benefits and document consent  
  – If lacking capacity, invoke emergency treatment laws or involve a substitute decision-maker  

• 6. Monitor continuously  
  – Check vital signs, consciousness level, and side effects  
  – Have resuscitation equipment and reversal agents at hand  

• 7. Document thoroughly  
  – Record assessments, rationale for medication choice, consent process, and patient response  

• 8. Debrief and follow up  
  – Review incident with the care team, adjust safety plans  
  – Arrange psychiatric evaluation and ongoing support
